abstract.p: Kay Reynolds letter comments on May 18 article on Japanese Garden in Prospect Park

block.p: Your superb article about the Japanese Garden in Prospect Park ''Human Nature: Revealing a Japanese Garden As Serene Melting Pot'' (May 18) brought back so many precious memories of long ago.
Your superb article about the Japanese Garden in Prospect Park ''Human Nature: Revealing a Japanese Garden As Serene Melting Pot'' (May 18) brought back so many precious memories of long ago.

I spent so much time in the Japanese Garden during the Great Depression. At that period of great stress, the company I worked for, instead of firing its employees, gave them a week off without pay each month. That was my precious joy time. I headed straight for the Japanese Garden.

My favorite was the Lotus Pond brimming with exquisite pink flowers on long stems. I sat crosslegged on the ground meditating on the symbolism of the lotus -- roots in the mud, aspiring stems reaching toward the beautiful blooms of the spirit.

So the dark mud of the Depression might be overcome by the questing spirit. I was still in my teens. All around me men were jumping out of windows in despair, unable to support their families. I always felt that the Japanese Garden, the lotus, the wisteria, got me through it.
Thank you for bringing such beautiful memories to me at 89 years of age.
